<p><strong>The COVID-19 pandemic</strong> has emerged as one of the most significant humanitarian challenges in recent history, and testing is seen as one of the main components of efforts to contain the virus and mitigate its impact.</p>
<p>There are two main testing technologies: molecular assays, which identify viral genetic material and signal the presence of a viral infection, and immunoassays, which identify antigens or antibodies. While both types of tests are considered important in developing a successful COVID-19-response strategy, this article focuses on molecular-assay testing, regarded as the confirmatory test for detecting active infectionsand specifically on laboratory-based molecular-assay tests as opposed to point-of-care tests. While the latter can play an important role in a testing strategy, they are deployed on a much smaller scale (see sidebar, Testing technologies).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Testing technologies</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong><em>There are two broad testing technologies:</em></strong></p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Molecular assays.</em> Molecular-assay testing, such as reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and isothermal amplification, identifies viral nucleic acid and signal the presence of a viral infection.</li>
    <li><em>Immunoassays. </em>Immunoassay testing identifies both antigens and antibodies:
    <ul>
        <li>Immunoassays that identify antibodies are used mainly to detect whether a person has been infected previously. In most cases, they cannot be used as a reliable diagnostic test to detect active COVID-19 infections.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote1" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="998fc43f-bc24-4be1-8a05-9a015992f735" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">1</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote1" class="tooltip"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">1.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="998fc43f-bc24-4be1-8a05-9a015992f735"><span></span>Serology testing for COVID-19 at CDC, US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, May 23, 2020, cdc.gov.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span> 
        It also remains unknown whether, for what period of time, and at what level of concentration antibodies confer any level of immunity.</li>
        <li>Immunoassays that identify COVID-19 antigens have recently been introduced and promise to be cost effective and fast, but they have not proven to be a substitute for the RT-PCR method for diagnosing active infections.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
</ul>
<p>Both of these technologies can be deployed in two different settings:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Laboratory. </em>Patient samples are collected in clinics, hospitals, and collection centers and transported to laboratories, where testing is executed and the results produced. Laboratory-based testing typically is large scale and needs more financial and operational investments.</li>
    <li><em>Point of care (POC).</em> POC tests are often executed in a hospital or clinic. By definition, POC testing has a lower throughput. Most POC molecular-assay tests need proprietary equipment and reagents. POC immunoassay tests typically leverage lateral-flow devices, similar to those deployed in pregnancy testing.</li>
</ul>
<p>As the testing landscape evolves, we expect the prominence of immunoassay tests and POC testing to increase.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Many regions around the world are experiencing a shortage of laboratory-based molecular-assay tests. In the United States, for example, testing capacity stands at between three and three-and-a-half million tests a week, well below even some of the most conservative estimates of the number required.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f21d7352-ca24-403d-92ae-dcc8afeca37c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f21d7352-ca24-403d-92ae-dcc8afeca37c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Brianna Abbott and Sarah Krouse, Coronavirus testing capacity is going unused, <em>Wall Street Journal, </em>April 29, 2020, wsj.com.</span></span></span></a></span> The estimated number needed ranges from six million tests a week (if the economy is to be partially reopened) to 20 million a day, representing 6 percent of the population each day (if it is to be fully reopened while still controlling outbreaks).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a0341910-25f7-43f9-a986-5f49349d16d5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a0341910-25f7-43f9-a986-5f49349d16d5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Roadmap to pandemic resilience: Massive scale testing, tracing, and supported isolation (TTSI) as the path to pandemic resilience for a free     society, Edmond J. Hows your state doing?, NPR, May 7, 2020, npr.org.</span></span></span></a></span> To put that into perspective, the current global capacity for molecular tests within laboratories is estimated to be around 14 million to 16 million tests a week, with the number of tests actually conducted being less than 10 million per week (Exhibit 1).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="27a42105-6119-4833-bdc4-c6e348a1bc57"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="27a42105-6119-4833-bdc4-c6e348a1bc57" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on estimates and figures available on May 7, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/covid%2019%20overcoming%20supply%20shortages%20for%20diagnostic%20testing/svgz-testingshortage-ex1-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Lab-based molecular-assay testing capacity remains well below estimates of the number of tests required." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/covid%2019%20overcoming%20supply%20shortages%20for%20diagnostic%20testing/svgz-testingshortage-ex1-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>Increasing the supply of testsas well as ensuring that they reach those who need themis therefore crucial. Even as disease-prevalence rates fall and economies reopen, identifying those who are infected will likely remain a priorityboth to treat and isolate them and to further epidemiological knowledge of the disease. This article examines where constraints in the process for delivering tests currently lie to help identify how efforts might be directed to ease them.</p>
<h2>Where constraints lie</h2>
<p>There are five main activities in the process for delivering laboratory-based molecular-assay tests: sample collection, logistics, test execution, data management, and testing-capacity management (Exhibit 2). (Data management is not examined in this article.) All activities need to be executed harmoniously to maximize supply in a complex testing ecosystem, but bottlenecks can occur at each point.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/covid%2019%20overcoming%20supply%20shortages%20for%20diagnostic%20testing/svgz-testingshortage-ex2-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The process of delivering of lab-based molecular-assay tests must be executed harmoniously to maximize supply in a complex testing environment." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/covid%2019%20overcoming%20supply%20shortages%20for%20diagnostic%20testing/svgz-testingshortage-ex2-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Sample collection</h3>
<p>Sample collection is required for all diagnostic testing. A shortage of the supplies needed to collect samples (such as swabs and viral-transport mediums) and a limited number of testing sites have sometimes led to long waiting times for a COVID-19 test and to key segments of the population (such as healthcare workers) going untested.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>Progress on addressing some of these issues has been made. To increase the supply of swabs, traditional manufacturers have increased capacity, new manufacturers have been approved, and some manufacturers are using 3-D printing. Some health authorities have approved alternative transport mediums (such as saline) and different types of samples (such as saliva and lower-respiratory-tract samples). Studies indicate that the test results from such alternatives could be as accurate as those taken from swabs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f056328a-226f-4125-b6e4-25107d72dcc9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f056328a-226f-4125-b6e4-25107d72dcc9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Anne Louise Wyllie et al., Saliva is more sensitive for SARS-CoV-2 detection in COVID-19 patients than nasopharyngeal swabs, medRxiv, April 22, 2020, medrxiv.org.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>To collect more samples, countries have also expanded testing sites by establishing drive- and walk-through testing centers. Such centers help reduce not only waiting times but also the risk of contagion to healthcare providers and others. At-home sample-collection methods are also emerging as relatively safe options and have been validated by several countries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8a89a57e-1b50-477c-b637-4f32ef25fc33"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8a89a57e-1b50-477c-b637-4f32ef25fc33" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Coronavirus (COVID-19) update: FDA authorizes first test for patient at-home sample collection, US Food and Drug Administration, April 21, 2020, fda.gov.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Logistics</h3>
<p>Logistics companies play a crucial role at two points in the testing supply chain: the shipment of components from sources around the world to testing laboratories and the transportation of samples from collection points to laboratories. Neither issue has proved to be as significant a constraint on testing as the other issues highlighted in this article. They could, however, become more problematic as countries (particularly those with emerging economies) expand testing, so both issues should be monitored closely.</p>
<h3>Test execution</h3>
<p>Two main challenges have led to a limited capacity to execute tests: a shortage of the laboratory equipment and trained personnel needed to run tests and a shortage of the necessary reagents, which are often packaged as kits (testing kits and RNA-extraction kits, for example).</p>
<p>Building and installing new equipment takes timebetween 20 and 30 days for an order of high-throughput equipment to be delivered, for instance, and at least three to five days for it to be installed, calibrated, and validated for diagnostic testing.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="93d0a5be-42c9-421a-9ac0-f64ccc48032c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="93d0a5be-42c9-421a-9ac0-f64ccc48032c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Roche COVID-19 blog: News and stories from the front line,</em> The importance of the global supply chain for COVID-19 diagnostics, blog entry, April 22, 2020, diagnostics.roche.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Newly installed equipment also requires more trained personnel to operate it. Moreover, financial constraints in many countriesgovernment funding for public health laboratories, for examplecan make it hard to build additional capacity.</p>
<p>Executing a test requires some 20 different reagents, consumables, and other pieces of equipment. Of those materials, major shortages have been reported in RNA-extraction kits and certain reagents, including enzymes and primers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="05a87ec1-030f-4b90-830f-4fe1df11aa2c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="05a87ec1-030f-4b90-830f-4fe1df11aa2c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Brianna Abbot, Shortage of test components forces labs to beg, borrow and improvise, <em>Wall Street Journal, </em>April 5, 2020, wsj.com</span></span></span></a></span> The global manufacturing capacity for molecular-assay tests is estimated to be between 37 million and 38 million tests a week, given current availability of the various test components, with RNA-extraction kits being the bottleneck to higher capacity (Exhibit 3).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6daaedea-0bf7-4b55-b659-67c4d5c3387b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6daaedea-0bf7-4b55-b659-67c4d5c3387b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on estimates and figures available on May 7, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> That compares with fewer than 10 million tests a week being conducted around the world, according to our research.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/covid%2019%20overcoming%20supply%20shortages%20for%20diagnostic%20testing/svgz-testingshortage-ex3-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="RNA-extraction kits are the bottleneck to higher global manufacturing capacity for molecular-assay tests." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/covid%2019%20overcoming%20supply%20shortages%20for%20diagnostic%20testing/svgz-testingshortage-ex3-vf2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>There are two potential explanations for the gap. First, a significant quantity of the reagents being manufactured are those that run on open systemsthat is, less integrated systems that can run a wider range of test methods. Such reagents cannot be used with the high-throughput machines that tend to be used in developed countries and are closed systems requiring cartridges loaded with proprietary reagents manufactured by the OEM. Second, as Exhibit 3 shows, most of the available manufacturing capacity is based in China, potentially making access to it more difficult, given validation and export considerations.</p>
<h3>Testing-capacity management</h3>
<p>In some countries, matching supply with demand has been a bottleneck, leaving available laboratory-testing capacity underutilized. Laboratories in various locations around the United States, for example, have reported unused capacity to conduct more tests, even as patients and healthcare workers report difficulty in securing tests.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="08dd97af-f1e2-4e5d-a84d-9058c39366c3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="08dd97af-f1e2-4e5d-a84d-9058c39366c3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Amy Maxmen, Thousands of coronavirus tests are going unused in US labs, <em>Nature, </em>2020, Volume 580, pp. 3123, nature.com.</span></span></span></a></span> A similar situation has arisen in the United Kingdom, where the number of completed tests has often lagged behind reported capacity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6b652cb5-1f69-4090-b5b6-90de217def60"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6b652cb5-1f69-4090-b5b6-90de217def60" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Rowena Mason, Less than half UKs Covid-19 testing capacity being used, figures show,<em> Guardian, </em>April 16, 2020, theguardian.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The same is true of supplies of reagents, test kits, and other consumables. In April 2020, Brazil reported that seven laboratories cleared by health regulators were unable to process tests because they did not have the reagents, even though they were available on the market.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a490c5f9-cdbd-4e00-878c-bbcddb054fcf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a490c5f9-cdbd-4e00-878c-bbcddb054fcf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ana Mano, As Brazils COVID-19 testing lags, available labs go unused, Reuters, April 15, 2020, uk.reuters.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Lack of coordination, experienced in locations around the world, has often led to unnecessary competition for supplies among regions and even among hospitals within a single region.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d4d79017-e566-42ce-82b8-8ef04be03f3e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d4d79017-e566-42ce-82b8-8ef04be03f3e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Anna Maria Barry-Jester, Rachel Bluth, and Angela Hart, Californias coronavirus testing still a frustrating patchwork of haves and have-nots, NPR, May 3, 2020, npr.org.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>Bridging the supplydemand gap</h2>
<p>The previously described constraints in the testing process that have emerged to date suggest what might be done to bridge the supplydemand gap. Some of the measures will bring about incremental improvements and others a step change, but both will likely be required to bridge the gap. Measures require different level of investments. And some are short-term measures capable of delivering results in as little as three months, while others will take longerpossibly up to a year or longer.</p>
<h3>Short-term measures</h3>
<p>Three measures could help maximize the utilization of existing resources in as few as three months.</p>
<p><strong><em>1. Establish visibility into testing capacity. </em></strong>A clear view of the unused testing capacity available is crucial if it is not to go to waste. Here, the establishment of information nerve centers that collect data on local capacity then match it with demand on a daily basis could help. As more capacity comes on stream, a nerve centers overview could also help health authorities expand testing quicklyfor example, offering tests not only to healthcare workers and those in hospital but also to vulnerable members of the community. Nerve centers could also act as a repositories for critical data on the inventory levels of consumables and testing reagents and on potential suppliers, helping governments and healthcare providers plan ahead and prevent shortages.</p>
<p><strong><em>2. Maximize existing laboratory capacity.</em></strong> Local laboratories may not be fully utilizing installed equipment for a number of reasons, ranging from suboptimized workflows to lack of trained personnel. Unlocking all available capacity starts by compiling a full inventory of the installed equipment base, distinguishing between open and closed systems, then calculating the maximum theoretical laboratory capacity, given the installed base. That allows companies to locate and address bottlenecks, be it by establishing new workflows, hiring additional personnel, or finding alternative suppliers of reagents if open-source systems are used. Universities and major diagnostic manufacturers could perhaps partner with local laboratories to help with some of those issuesproviding open-system equipment they have in their own research facilities, reagents, and trained personnel, for example.</p>
<p><strong><em>3. Establish new laboratory capacity.</em></strong> Laboratory capacity can be raised by increasing the equipment footprint in existing laboratories and by establishing new, high-capacity laboratories. Collaboration among governments, public-health organizations, equipment manufacturers, and private laboratories can accelerate such efforts. Novacyt, a UK and French diagnostics company, has collaborated with AstraZeneca, GlaxoSmithKline, and the University of Cambridge to increase testing capacity in the United Kingdom, for example.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="13c3bb7e-a080-4215-a4d1-c6ad9f1b01c1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="13c3bb7e-a080-4215-a4d1-c6ad9f1b01c1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sean Whooley, Novacyt joins collaboration to boost COVID-19 testing in UK, MassDevice, April 8, 2020, massdevice.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>As shortages of testing kits can cause bottlenecks within laboratories, an important consideration when installing new capacity is which type of equipment to install: open systems, which can run a wider range of test methods, or closed systems, which require proprietary reagents manufactured by OEMs. The choice could have a significant impact on future testing capacity, as reagents for open systems are manufactured by considerably more suppliers.</p>
<p>If open systems are chosen, health authorities may still wish to consider evaluating and validating new sources of supply to mitigate the risk of future shortages. Establishing a centralized repository that holds information on the performance of various kits and their components could help speed the validation and approval processes. And prioritizing the validation of suppliers with high capacity would likely grant faster access to additional manufacturing capacity.</p>
<h3>Medium-term measures</h3>
<p>Two measures could boost capacity in the medium term (that is, between three months and a year or longer).</p>
<p><strong><em>1. Scale up production of closed-system cartridges and proprietary reagents.</em></strong> One of the main reasons that laboratories using closed-system equipment have been underutilized during the current pandemic is a shortage of the OEMs cartridges loaded with proprietary reagents. To utilize these systems closer to their theoretical maximum capacity, OEMs will need to ramp up production volumes, though doing so is a tough decision to make, given the costs involved and the risks when long-term demand is uncertain.</p>
<p><strong><em>2. Explore alternative testing protocols and curve shifting technologies. </em></strong>As previously mentioned, alternative protocols for sample collection and testing can help increase testing capacity and alleviate shortages of particular components, and some of these protocols have already been validated by various authorities. In addition, sample pooling can be used to decrease the quantities of reagents needed.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3ca0c6f2-ca97-4355-94f4-adf428b9cf8d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3ca0c6f2-ca97-4355-94f4-adf428b9cf8d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Haran Shani-Narkiss et al., Efficient and practical sample pooling for high-throughput PCR diagnosis of COVID-19, medRxiv, April 14, 2020, medrxiv.org.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>New and potentially curve-shifting testing technologies can also be explored. For instance, large-scale next-generation sequencing can potentially run up to 100,000 pooled samples in a single machine in eight to 12 hours. That could increase testing capacity by an order of magnitude, assuming the availability of reagents, instruments, heating capacity, and trained personnel to preprocess samples. Such technologies are still in the research phase, but there may be an opportunity to validate and scale them rapidly once real-world evidence of their performance is available.</p>
<p>New techniques could also facilitate more at-home tests. For instance, companies such as Caspr Biotech, Mammoth Biosciences, and Sherlock Biosciences are developing at-home, CRISPR-based tests that utilize reagents different from those in traditional molecular-assay tests.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="08bb01a6-b178-4e27-8b3f-34d80183935b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="08bb01a6-b178-4e27-8b3f-34d80183935b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jim Daley, CRISPR gene editing may help scale up coronavirus testing, Scientific American, April 23, 2020, scientificamerican.com; Neel V. Patel and Antonio Regalado, The race is on for a covid-19 test you can take at home, <em>MIT Technology Review, </em>May 20, 2020, technologyreview.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<hr>
<p>Impressive efforts by public and private bodies alike have seen the rapid escalation of the capacity of laboratory-based molecular-assay testing in some regions, but there are opportunities around the world to increase it further. Focusing efforts on a select set of high-impact measures, as described in this article, could make an important difference. As immunoassay testing begins to play a larger role in local and global responses to the COVID-19 pandemic, similar analysis and focus will be needed to increase testing capacity. Without doubt, increasing testing capacity is a daunting challenge, but it is one that needs to be met to help ensure more reliable virus control and more sustainable economic recovery.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/mohammad-behnam">Mohammad Behnam</a></strong>, PhD, is a partner in McKinseys Vancouver office, <strong>Arnav Dey </strong>is a consultant in the Boston office,  <strong><a href="/our-people/tony-gambell">Tony Gambell</a> </strong>is a partner in the Chicago office, and <strong>Vaibhav Talwar </strong>is an associate partner in the New Jersey office.</p>

Overcoming supply shortages for diagnostic testing"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Testing is considered critical to containing COVID-19, yet many  countries have encountered diagnostic-supply shortages. Understanding where constraints lie could help efforts to scale testing."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-07-15T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic\u003c/strong\u003e has emerged as one of the most significant humanitarian challenges in recent history, and testing is seen as one of the main components of efforts to contain the virus and mitigate its impact.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are two main testing technologies: molecular assays, which identify viral genetic material and signal the presence of a viral infection, and immunoassays, which identify antigens or antibodies. While both types of tests are considered important in developing a successful COVID-19-response strategy, this article focuses on molecular-assay testing, regarded as the confirmatory test for detecting active infections\u0026mdash;and specifically on laboratory-based molecular-assay tests as opposed to point-of-care tests. While the latter can play an important role in a testing strategy, they are deployed on a much smaller scale (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;Testing technologies\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar Testing]]\n\u003cp\u003eMany regions around the world are experiencing a shortage of laboratory-based molecular-assay tests. In the United States, for example, testing capacity stands at between three and three-and-a-half million tests a week, well below even some of the most conservative estimates of the number required.[[Footnote 1]] The estimated number needed ranges from six million tests a week (if the economy is to be partially reopened) to 20 million a day, representing 6 percent of the population each day (if it is to be fully reopened while still controlling outbreaks).[[Footnote 2]] To put that into perspective, the current global capacity for molecular tests within laboratories is estimated to be around 14 million to 16 million tests a week, with the number of tests actually conducted being less than 10 million per week (Exhibit 1).[[Footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eIncreasing the supply of tests\u0026mdash;as well as ensuring that they reach those who need them\u0026mdash;is therefore crucial. Even as disease-prevalence rates fall and economies reopen, identifying those who are infected will likely remain a priority\u0026mdash;both to treat and isolate them and to further epidemiological knowledge of the disease. This article examines where constraints in the process for delivering tests currently lie to help identify how efforts might be directed to ease them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhere constraints lie\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are five main activities in the process for delivering laboratory-based molecular-assay tests: sample collection, logistics, test execution, data management, and testing-capacity management (Exhibit 2). (Data management is not examined in this article.) All activities need to be executed harmoniously to maximize supply in a complex testing ecosystem, but bottlenecks can occur at each point.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003ch3\u003eSample collection\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSample collection is required for all diagnostic testing. A shortage of the supplies needed to collect samples (such as swabs and viral-transport mediums) and a limited number of testing sites have sometimes led to long waiting times for a COVID-19 test and to key segments of the population (such as healthcare workers) going untested.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Ceros covid]]\n\u003cp\u003eProgress on addressing some of these issues has been made. To increase the supply of swabs, traditional manufacturers have increased capacity, new manufacturers have been approved, and some manufacturers are using 3-D printing. Some health authorities have approved alternative transport mediums (such as saline) and different types of samples (such as saliva and lower-respiratory-tract samples). Studies indicate that the test results from such alternatives could be as accurate as those taken from swabs.[[Footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo collect more samples, countries have also expanded testing sites by establishing drive- and walk-through testing centers. Such centers help reduce not only waiting times but also the risk of contagion to healthcare providers and others. At-home sample-collection methods are also emerging as relatively safe options and have been validated by several countries.[[Footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eLogistics\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLogistics companies play a crucial role at two points in the testing supply chain: the shipment of components from sources around the world to testing laboratories and the transportation of samples from collection points to laboratories. Neither issue has proved to be as significant a constraint on testing as the other issues highlighted in this article. They could, however, become more problematic as countries (particularly those with emerging economies) expand testing, so both issues should be monitored closely.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTest execution\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTwo main challenges have led to a limited capacity to execute tests: a shortage of the laboratory equipment and trained personnel needed to run tests and a shortage of the necessary reagents, which are often packaged as kits (testing kits and RNA-extraction kits, for example).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBuilding and installing new equipment takes time\u0026mdash;between 20 and 30 days for an order of high-throughput equipment to be delivered, for instance, and at least three to five days for it to be installed, calibrated, and validated for diagnostic testing.[[Footnote 6]] Newly installed equipment also requires more trained personnel to operate it. Moreover, financial constraints in many countries\u0026mdash;government funding for public health laboratories, for example\u0026mdash;can make it hard to build additional capacity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExecuting a test requires some 20 different reagents, consumables, and other pieces of equipment. Of those materials, major shortages have been reported in RNA-extraction kits and certain reagents, including enzymes and primers.[[Footnote 7]] The global manufacturing capacity for molecular-assay tests is estimated to be between 37 million and 38 million tests a week, given current availability of the various test components, with RNA-extraction kits being the bottleneck to higher capacity (Exhibit 3).[[Footnote 8]] That compares with fewer than 10 million tests a week being conducted around the world, according to our research.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eThere are two potential explanations for the gap. First, a significant quantity of the reagents being manufactured are those that run on open systems\u0026mdash;that is, less integrated systems that can run a wider range of test methods. Such reagents cannot be used with the high-throughput machines that tend to be used in developed countries and are closed systems requiring cartridges loaded with proprietary reagents manufactured by the OEM. Second, as Exhibit 3 shows, most of the available manufacturing capacity is based in China, potentially making access to it more difficult, given validation and export considerations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTesting-capacity management\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn some countries, matching supply with demand has been a bottleneck, leaving available laboratory-testing capacity underutilized. Laboratories in various locations around the United States, for example, have reported unused capacity to conduct more tests, even as patients and healthcare workers report difficulty in securing tests.[[Footnote 9]] A similar situation has arisen in the United Kingdom, where the number of completed tests has often lagged behind reported capacity.[[Footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe same is true of supplies of reagents, test kits, and other consumables. In April 2020, Brazil reported that seven laboratories cleared by health regulators were unable to process tests because they did not have the reagents, even though they were available on the market.[[Footnote 11]] Lack of coordination, experienced in locations around the world, has often led to unnecessary competition for supplies among regions and even among hospitals within a single region.[[Footnote 12]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eBridging the supply\u0026ndash;demand gap\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe previously described constraints in the testing process that have emerged to date suggest what might be done to bridge the supply\u0026ndash;demand gap. Some of the measures will bring about incremental improvements and others a step change, but both will likely be required to bridge the gap. Measures require different level of investments. And some are short-term measures capable of delivering results in as little as three months, while others will take longer\u0026mdash;possibly up to a year or longer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eShort-term measures\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThree measures could help maximize the utilization of existing resources in as few as three months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e1. Establish visibility into testing capacity. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003eA clear view of the unused testing capacity available is crucial if it is not to go to waste. Here, the establishment of information nerve centers that collect data on local capacity then match it with demand on a daily basis could help. As more capacity comes on stream, a nerve center\u0026rsquo;s overview could also help health authorities expand testing quickly\u0026mdash;for example, offering tests not only to healthcare workers and those in hospital but also to vulnerable members of the community. Nerve centers could also act as a repositories for critical data on the inventory levels of consumables and testing reagents and on potential suppliers, helping governments and healthcare providers plan ahead and prevent shortages.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e2. Maximize existing laboratory capacity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Local laboratories may not be fully utilizing installed equipment for a number of reasons, ranging from suboptimized workflows to lack of trained personnel. Unlocking all available capacity starts by compiling a full inventory of the installed equipment base, distinguishing between open and closed systems, then calculating the maximum theoretical laboratory capacity, given the installed base. That allows companies to locate and address bottlenecks, be it by establishing new workflows, hiring additional personnel, or finding alternative suppliers of reagents if open-source systems are used. Universities and major diagnostic manufacturers could perhaps partner with local laboratories to help with some of those issues\u0026mdash;providing open-system equipment they have in their own research facilities, reagents, and trained personnel, for example.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e3. Establish new laboratory capacity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Laboratory capacity can be raised by increasing the equipment footprint in existing laboratories and by establishing new, high-capacity laboratories. Collaboration among governments, public-health organizations, equipment manufacturers, and private laboratories can accelerate such efforts. Novacyt, a UK and French diagnostics company, has collaborated with AstraZeneca, GlaxoSmithKline, and the University of Cambridge to increase testing capacity in the United Kingdom, for example.[[Footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs shortages of testing kits can cause bottlenecks within laboratories, an important consideration when installing new capacity is which type of equipment to install: open systems, which can run a wider range of test methods, or closed systems, which require proprietary reagents manufactured by OEMs. The choice could have a significant impact on future testing capacity, as reagents for open systems are manufactured by considerably more suppliers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf open systems are chosen, health authorities may still wish to consider evaluating and validating new sources of supply to mitigate the risk of future shortages. Establishing a centralized repository that holds information on the performance of various kits and their components could help speed the validation and approval processes. And prioritizing the validation of suppliers with high capacity would likely grant faster access to additional manufacturing capacity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMedium-term measures\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTwo measures could boost capacity in the medium term (that is, between three months and a year or longer).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e1. Scale up production of closed-system cartridges and proprietary reagents.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e One of the main reasons that laboratories using closed-system equipment have been underutilized during the current pandemic is a shortage of the OEMs\u0026rsquo; cartridges loaded with proprietary reagents. To utilize these systems closer to their theoretical maximum capacity, OEMs will need to ramp up production volumes, though doing so is a tough decision to make, given the costs involved and the risks when long-term demand is uncertain.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e2. Explore alternative testing protocols and \u0026lsquo;curve shifting\u0026rsquo; technologies. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003eAs previously mentioned, alternative protocols for sample collection and testing can help increase testing capacity and alleviate shortages of particular components, and some of these protocols have already been validated by various authorities. In addition, sample pooling can be used to decrease the quantities of reagents needed.[[Footnote 14]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNew and potentially curve-shifting testing technologies can also be explored. For instance, large-scale next-generation sequencing can potentially run up to 100,000 pooled samples in a single machine in eight to 12 hours. That could increase testing capacity by an order of magnitude, assuming the availability of reagents, instruments, heating capacity, and trained personnel to preprocess samples. Such technologies are still in the research phase, but there may be an opportunity to validate and scale them rapidly once real-world evidence of their performance is available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNew techniques could also facilitate more at-home tests. For instance, companies such as Caspr Biotech, Mammoth Biosciences, and Sherlock Biosciences are developing at-home, CRISPR-based tests that utilize reagents different from those in traditional molecular-assay tests.[[Footnote 15]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eImpressive efforts by public and private bodies alike have seen the rapid escalation of the capacity of laboratory-based molecular-assay testing in some regions, but there are opportunities around the world to increase it further. Focusing efforts on a select set of high-impact measures, as described in this article, could make an important difference. As immunoassay testing begins to play a larger role in local and global responses to the COVID-19 pandemic, similar analysis and focus will be needed to increase testing capacity. Without doubt, increasing testing capacity is a daunting challenge, but it is one that needs to be met to help ensure more reliable virus control and more sustainable economic recovery.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-07-15T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBrianna Abbott and Sarah Krouse, \u0026ldquo;Coronavirus testing capacity is going unused,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eWall Street Journal, \u003c/em\u003eApril 29, 2020, wsj.com.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Roadmap to pandemic resilience: Massive scale testing, tracing, and supported isolation (TTSI) as the path to pandemic resilience for a free     society,\u0026rdquo; Edmond J. testing technologies:\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMolecular assays.\u003c/em\u003e Molecular-assay testing, such as reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and isothermal amplification, identifies viral nucleic acid and signal the presence of a viral infection.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eImmunoassays. \u003c/em\u003eImmunoassay testing identifies both antigens and antibodies:\n    \u003cul\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eImmunoassays that identify antibodies are used mainly to detect whether a person has been infected previously. In most cases, they cannot be used as a reliable diagnostic test to detect active COVID-19 infections.\u003ca href=\"#\" class=\"link-footnote\" onclick=\"return false;\" rel=\"#footnote1\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e1\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote1\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e1.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\u0026ldquo;Serology testing for COVID-19 at CDC,\u0026rdquo; US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, May 23, 2020, cdc.gov.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n        It also remains unknown whether, for what period of time, and at what level of concentration antibodies confer any level of immunity.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eImmunoassays that identify COVID-19 antigens have recently been introduced and promise to be cost effective and fast, but they have not proven to be a substitute for the RT-PCR method for diagnosing active infections.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBoth of these technologies can be deployed in two different settings:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLaboratory. \u003c/em\u003ePatient samples are collected in clinics, hospitals, and collection centers and transported to laboratories, where testing is executed and the results produced. Laboratory-based testing typically is large scale and needs more financial and operational investments.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePoint of care (POC).\u003c/em\u003e POC tests are often executed in a hospital or clinic. By definition, POC testing has a lower throughput. Most POC molecular-assay tests need proprietary equipment and reagents. POC immunoassay tests typically leverage lateral-flow devices, similar to those deployed in pregnancy testing.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs the testing landscape evolves, we expect the prominence of immunoassay tests and POC testing to increase.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Testing
